title.narrative: CUBES: A pathway to enabling Brazilian leadership in ground-based astronomy

description.narrative: Long-term sustainable growth in Brazil requires increased capability for innovation in high-tech sectors, but recent economic challenges are threatening investment in scientific research. This proposal will enhance the science base in Brazil in a research area where it is well positioned for international leadership if given the right support and resources, Astronomy is one of the most accessible areas of contemporary scientific research. Here we propose UK support of Brazil's ambition to develop a world-leading instrument ('CUBES') for the European Southern Observatory (ESO). The proposed activities will help build Brazilian science capacity and upskill its engineers. They will help Brazil improve its scientific and industrial return in astronomy, in support of its economic development. They will also position Brazilian engineers and researchers to lead future international projects, from which they can act as mentors to inspire the next generation.

We propose UK support of the Brazilian work in the next phase of the CUBES instrument for the Very Large Telescope, building on our successful Newton Fund networking activities with Brazil in 2015-16. The proposed work will bring the extensive expertise of the engineers and scientists at the UK Astronomy Technology Centre (UKATC) to the CUBES project, with the following objectives: * To build Brazilian capacity and expertise in opto-mechanical, electrical, and software engineering, via upskilling from collaborative work. * To train Brazilian engineers and scientists in working with ESO, via the knowledge at the UKATC of ESO standards and processes, and the rigorous testing and commissioning activities required for an instrument to be successful once delivered. * To provide secondment opportunities in the UK for Brazilian early-stage researchers. * To strengthen scientific and technical collaboration between the UK and Brazil, enhancing Brazilian leadership and international prestige in high-profile research. * To forge a strong partnership between astronomical institutes in Brazil and the UK, ultimately toward future ELT instrumentation and science.
